messages.content:
I need random numbers in smart contract. Previously I saw @ember were suggesting 
"As to your concrete question, you can safely rely on the entropy of the epoch seeds (see Mina.getNetworkState), which are protected by consensus and seed the VRF used for slot leader selection (can’t get any more secure than this)."
https://discord.com/channels/484437221055922177/1210200684922798090/1210223126420389969

I see this.network.stakingEpochData.seed field, but as I can understand it is updated once on epoche start. 
Is there some random values per slot?
I guess you want something that is not predictable before that block exists?
Otherwise just hash the staking epoch data plus the slot number
Yes. The idea was that user send his transaction and in several blocks we call function that generate random for him using some data from block
We can't use block hash for that because it can be easily manipulated. But I saw the response with "entropy of the epoch seeds" and was interested if we can use that.
@Alekasndr Ivlev combine them
But it will be as easy to manipulate as just a block hash, isn't it?
Block ashes in mina are unpredictable due to the combination of the market activity, recorded inside of the block, as well as the epoch seed recorded for the entire epoch
Source any additional entropy thru interaction with the contract

If block hashes are upredictable - why we can't just use them? I thought that the main problem with randomness form blockhash is that block producer can easily manipulate it. Why do we need stakingEpoch.seed?
You are correct with the problem, but the epoch seed combines all the entropy from individual block producers so no one party can manipulate.
But if we do hash(epochSeed, blockHash), it as as easy to manipulate as just blockhash. And epochSeed is updated too rarely to use it by itself
This is why i suggest sourcing additional entropy by contract interaction; applying the same technique that Ouroboros itself uses but in your “appchain”

Hmmmm,I need to explore more how Ouroboros do it. The problem with in-contract entropy, that users can influence the result of random, and it can lead to security issues. But maybe there is a way to do it secure
Tagging @şef as well, there is a team who will be focusing on this one - any input would be helpful.
There is a way to do it secure: monoid it together with the secure entropy that the protocol provides.

Hey, as @Yasin stated, there is another team who will get randomnes fromm **Drand- Distributed Randomness Beacon**. Regarding your question - Using the epoch and an additional 'random' number can work as well right ? I haven't thought about mathematical analysis of it but if you get get the data from epoch and also add somethings from user (not a manual input necessarily, but a signature that is again somehow created by user with a random message in the process) can work as increasing the entropy.
It looks like I have a hell of a lot to read 😁
Yep, the other teams in the space need all the luck they can get.
If you haven’t thought about the mathematical analysis, keep your hands out of the code, and don’t ever ever ever put your money into a Mina smart contract.
We are building a lottery game. So if we are using user input to generate random, the last user that would participate in it would be able to change random generation result, so his tikket would win.
The grinding problem.
Okay, i see now. I didn't know it was lottery gmae
is there a way to generate a random number but restricting it to a set of Field? e.g Field(1) .... Field(20)

you mean, derive a number between 1 and 20 in a provable way from a seed?
or just, how to create a random number between 1 and 20 outside provable code?
both  options so I understand and also figure out which is preferrable...thanks

Do we know how much entropy is available to the VRF function? Much like the lottery, lets say I want to create a card game. I would need ~226 bits of entropy to securely be able to enumerate all the combinations of a card shuffle equally. 52! ~= 2^226
